text: in this video we will use the weekly
demo template to break down honeycomb's
formula syntax
showing the find row and today functions
let's start by viewing the app the home
screen has a pick list honeycomb's
version of a drop down menu
that is set to show today's date or the
next closest available date
for context today is september 4th
to select a date in the past you have to
click on the pick list
this setting is a handy way to keep your
app looking up to date
and displaying the most current data to
your users
let's look at the builder to see how
this is set up
the pick list display is set to the m
schedule table
pick lists and apps by default show the
first column of a row link
so this weak text column is what is
being presented in the app
the data tab shows that the pick list is
editable
this needs to be checked to give your
app users the drop down effect
the set initial value field configures
what will be displayed to the user when
they land on the screen
this formula uses the find row and today
function
so that when the app user lands on the
home screen they see either today's date
or the next available date in the future
let's break down the syntax
formulas always start with an equal sign
this tells honeycomb that everything
that follows is part of the formula
the find row function is a more powerful
version of a vlookup
instead of returning a single value like
a vlookup does
honey honeycomb's find row function
returns a
row link or an entire row of data
the find row function scans from top to
bottom
and returns the first row link that
matches whatever conditions
are inside of the parentheses
functions require parentheses to be
activated
and they wrap around the conditions
inside the parentheses we always start
with either the table
or the filter formula then optionally
you can add conditions and wrap them in
quotes
the today function doesn't take
arguments
so its parentheses are left empty
in this case honeycomb is being told to
go to the
m schedule table then once in the m
schedule table
to scan the date column from top to
bottom
and return the first row whose date
value
is greater than or equal to today which
means
find today's date and if you don't find
today's date find the next available
date in the future so if today were
september 5th
honeycode would skip 8 21 and 9
4 and instead present september 18th
in the app when the user first navigates
to the home screen
thanks for watching
